ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I completed a long-term project in creative writing, working diligently through the process of drafting and revising short stories with the help of an adviser and community of writers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the best parts of my experience in the concentration was my advisor. They read every iteration of my stories with care, and offered constructive, generative advice every time. Even on days where I felt crummy about the work I'd produced, my advisor found the good in it, and encouraged me to see my ideas through to the end. And I think that's probably one of the best things about the experience of the Writing Concentration: you learn how to undertake a large, expansive project, and how to tough-it out through those periods in the writing process where you want to scrap everything and quit. It's an experience that will teach you resilience, and while it can be extremely challenging, it is altogether very rewarding. And oftentimes, very fun.
Strengths: the group of writers in the Writing Concentration and the chance to work closely with faculty to focus on writing in a way that's not always possible in other writing classes

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. It's a lot of work, but you will undoubtedly become a better writer. Plan early, meet your self-imposed deadlines, and you can't go wrong.
Yes if you are able to find the time to focus on it

While the experience of working on a long-term project with an advisor is so rewarding and meaningful, and while I really admired and respected the other students in my cohort, I would honestly not recommend the Writing Concentration while Cynthia Zarin is running the program. Not only were our group meetings not very helpful, but Professor Zarin was regularly dismissive and unkind to students both in one-on-one meetings and in front of everyone else for no apparent reason. For one (relatively mild, but typical) example, she once responded to a classmate's project update, "You know the deadline is in two weeks, right?," implying that their project was not as developed as that classmate had initially thought. This response seemed, at the very least, unhelpful, if not humiliating. I was nervous before every meeting, and I know that I am not the only student who felt this way. I have never written a course evaluation like this before, but the Writing Concentration added so much stress to an already difficult semester and I want future creative writing students to know that if they experience this, they are not alone. I would advise younger students to consider an independent study in creative writing rather than the Concentration.
